{{Religious freedom |expanded=all}} Freedom of religion in [[Australia]] is allowed in practice and protected to varying degrees through the constitution and legislation at the [[Government of Australia|Federal]], [[States and territories of Australia|State and Territory]] level.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Completed_Inquiries/jfadt/Religion/issues|title=Australia's Efforts to Promote and Protect Freedom of Religion and Belief|last=|first=|date=|website=www.aph.gov.au|language=en-AU|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-22}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.humanrights.gov.au/submissions/religious-freedom-review-2018|title=Religious Freedom Review (2018)|last=ahrc.admin|first=|date=2018-02-14|website=www.humanrights.gov.au|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-22}} Australia is a [[Secular state|secular country]] with legislated [[separation of church and state]] and with no [[state religion]]. The nation has over 13.5 million people who identify as religious and 7.1 million who identify as [[Irreligion in Australia|irreligious]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.abs.gov.au/AUSSTATS/abs@.nsf/DetailsPage/1266.02016?OpenDocument#Data|title=2016 Census - Cultural Diversity|last=Australian Bureau of Statistics|first=|date=|website=www.abs.gov.au|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-23}} Relevant legislation protecting religious freedoms include sections of the [[Constitution of Australia]], Federal anti-[[discrimination]] laws and State/Territory-based human rights acts and anti-discrimination laws. As these freedoms are not protected in a single piece of legislation, but rather appear as sections, clauses and exemptions in other acts or laws, legal religious freedom protections are often a source of great debate and difficult to discern in Australia. == Religious freedom laws == === Federal level === The [[Constitution of Australia]] prohibits the Commonwealth from establishing laws which create, force or prohibit any religion. It also restricts the Commonwealth from using religion as a qualifier or test in order to hold public office. [[Section 116 of the Constitution of Australia|Section 116]] of ''Chapter V. The States'' in the [[Australian Constitution]] reads:
''The Commonwealth shall not make any law for establishing any religion, or for imposing any religious observance, or for prohibiting the free exercise of any religion, and no religious test shall be required as a qualification for any office or public trust under the Commonwealth.''{{Cite web|url=https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Senate/Powers_practice_n_procedures/Constitution/chapter5|title=Chapter V. The States.|last=|first=|date=|website=www.aph.gov.au|language=en-AU|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-22}}
The section is based on the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution]]. The article does not prohibit the [[States and territories of Australia|States of Australia]] from implementing such laws, meaning legislation at the state level could provide for restriction or enforcement of religion. === State and Territory level === Two [[referendum]]s were held on whether to restrict the ability of states to legislate laws that may impede religious freedoms: the [[Australian Post-War Reconstruction and Democratic Rights referendum, 1944]] and [[Australian referendum, 1988]]. Both failed to achieve a majority of support amongst the states and therefore did not pass into law. In theory, Australian State and Territory Governments can therefore pass laws impeding religious freedoms. Some states and territories have implemented a bill or charter of rights which include freedom and protection for religion, such as ''Section 14: Freedom of thought, conscience, religion and belief'' in: * ''[[Human Rights Act 2004]]'' ([[Australian Capital Territory]]){{Cite web|url=http://www6.austlii.edu.au/cgi-bin/viewdb/au/legis/act/consol_act/hra2004148/|title=HUMAN RIGHTS ACT 2004|website=www6.austlii.edu.au|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}} * [[Victorian Charter of Human Rights and Responsibilities|''Charter of Human Rights & Responsibilities Act 2006'']] ([[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]){{Cite web|url=http://www6.austlii.edu.au/cgi-bin/viewdb/au/legis/vic/consol_act/cohrara2006433/|title=CHARTER OF HUMAN RIGHTS AND RESPONSIBILITIES ACT 2006|website=www6.austlii.edu.au|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}} These legislated acts are based on the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]], to which Australia was a signatory in 1966 despite no direct legislation to permit these freedoms. These acts do not prevent the passing of laws that impede any rights mentioned (including religious freedoms), but they do create a process by which all legislation must be scrutinised for human rights implications, and must be accompanied by a statement of compatibility with human rights before they can be passed by the relevant Parliament. In cases where the legislation is not compatible, it may still be passed despite contradicting these human rights acts. == Anti-discrimination laws == Anti-discrimination laws addressing unfair treatment on the basis of a range of attributes, including religion, also apply at the state and federal level. These laws contribute to religious freedoms by allowing Australians to practice religion without fear of consequence from the executive, organisations or individuals. This is achieved by prohibiting detrimental treatment as a result of an individual's religious appearance, beliefs or observances. Some argue these laws are inconsistent at the state level and may be limited at the federal level. === Federal level === The ''[[Australian Human Rights Commission Act 1986]]'' defines discrimination as:
''(a) any distinction, exclusion or preference made on the basis of race, colour, sex, '''religion''', political opinion, national extraction or social origin that has the effect of nullifying or impairing equality of opportunity or treatment in employment or occupation;''{{Cite web|url=https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/C2017C00143|title=Australian Human Rights Commission Act 1986|last=AG|website=www.legislation.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}}
=== State and Territory level === State and Territory legislation prohibits unfavourable treatment on the basis of an individual's personal characteristics, but to varying degrees and with varying detail. Personal characteristics includes religious beliefs or activities in anti-discrimination legislation for the majority of states, and as such these laws may be seen to support religious freedom by prohibiting unfair treatment using religion as a basis.{{Cite web|url=https://www.canberratimes.com.au/national/act/religious-freedom-should-be-protected-for-all-australians-20180519-p4zgc7.html|title=Religious freedom should be protected for all Australians|website=Canberra Times|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-22}} Further, anti-discrimination acts States where religious beliefs and activities are protected include: *''Equal Opportunity Act 1984'' ([[Western Australia]]) *''Discrimination Act 1991'' (Australian Capital Territory) *''[[Anti-Discrimination Act 1991]]'' ([[Queensland]]) *''Anti-Discrimination Act 1996'' ([[Northern Territory]]) *''Anti-Discrimination Act 1998'' ([[Tasmania]]) *''[[Equal Opportunity Act 2010]]'' (Victoria){{Cite web|url=https://www.humanrights.gov.au/employers/good-practice-good-business-factsheets/quick-guide-australian-discrimination-laws|title=A quick guide to Australian discrimination laws|last=Kwan|first=Connie|date=2015-02-11|website=www.humanrights.gov.au|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-22}} Two other state acts apply narrower protection to '[[Religious clothing|religious appearance or dress]]' (''Equal Opportunity Act 1984'', [[South Australia]]) and '[[Ethnoreligious group|Ethno-religious]] or [[Nationality|national origin]]' (''[[Anti-Discrimination Act 1977]]'', [[New South Wales]]). It has been suggested that both states update their laws in order to align to the rest of the States and Territories.{{Cite web|url=https://vac.org.au/site/assets/uploaded/9dcc87b5-vac_religious_freedom_review_final.pdf|title=Submission to the Religious Freedom Review|last=Victorian Aids Council|first=|date=|website=vac.org.au|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=23 June 2018}} === Religious exemptions === General religious exception or exemption clauses exist within the various federal and state human rights acts with the aim to ensuring religious activities or observances are not impacted or inhibited by the protections provided by each act. These exemptions therefore protect freedom of religion by permitting what would otherwise be considered discrimination if it is in the context of "an act or practice of a body established for religious purposes that conforms to the doctrines, tenets or beliefs of that religion or is necessary to avoid injury to the religious sensitivities of adherents of that religion."{{Cite web|url=https://www.ag.gov.au/RightsAndProtections/FOI/Documents/Commonwealth%20Anti-Discrimination%20Legislation.pdf|title=List of Exemptions in Commonwealth Anti-Discrimination Legislation|last=|first=|date=|website=Attorney General of Australia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=23 June 2018}} In the case of the ''Australian Human Rights Commission Act 1986'', for example, an exemption is provided:
''Discrimination ... does not include any distinction, exclusion or preference:''
''(d) in connection with employment as a member of the staff of an institution that is conducted in accordance with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed, being a distinction, exclusion or preference made in good faith '''in order to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion or that creed.'''''
Varying groups have argued that existing religious exceptions and exemptions go too far and impede the rights of individuals,{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/yes-victors-seek-abolition-of-all-church-exemptions-to-anti-discrimination-laws-20180214-p4z0aj.html|title='Yes' victors seek abolition of all church exemptions to anti-discrimination laws|last=Koziol|first=Michael|date=2018-02-14|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}} whilst others argue the correct balance has been struck,{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/jan/07/labor-has-no-plans-to-change-law-allowing-religious-schools-to-fire-gay-teachers|title=Labor has 'no plans' to change law allowing religious schools to fire gay teachers|last=Karp|first=Paul|date=2018-01-07|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}} and yet others petition for wider-reaching religious exemption clauses.{{Cite news|url=https://www.acl.org.au/acl-contributes-to-the-australian-human-rights-commissions-religious-freedom-roundtable|title=ACL contributes to the Australian Human Rights Commission’s Religious Freedom Roundtable|work=Australian Christian Lobby|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en}} == Judgements and interpretations == {{See also|Section 116 of the Constitution of Australia}} [[File:Court 2 at the High Court of Australia.jpg|thumb|Court 2 of the High Court of Australia, [[Canberra]]. The High Court has issued few judgements in direct relation to freedom of religion]] There have been few tests involving religious freedom put before the [[High Court of Australia]]. Judgements from the Court are generally considered to interpret the primary piece of legislation relating to religious freedom, Section 116, narrowly.{{Cite book|title=Treading on Sacred Grounds: Places of Worship, Local Planning and Religious Freedom in Australia|last=Villaroman|first=Noel|publisher=Brill Nijhoff|year=2015|isbn=978-90-04-28933-8|edition=12|location=Boston|pages=103}} === Church of the New Faith v Commissioner for Pay-Roll Tax (Vic) === In the 1983 judgment of the High Court in ''Church of the New Faith v Commissioner for Pay-Roll Tax (Vic)'', the court was primarily concerned with whether [[Scientology]] was a religion (and therefore deserved [[tax exemption]]t status). In judgement, the Court found that [[Scientology]] was a religion and argued that the definition of religion must be flexible, but also remain sceptical of false claims. Justices [[Ronald Wilson]] and [[William Deane]] set out five "[[wikt:indicia|indicia]]" of a religion:
(i) That the collection of ideas and practices involved a belief in the supernatural (being something that could not be perceived by the senses); (ii) That 'the ideas relate to man's nature and place in the universe and his relation to things supernatural' ; (iii) That the adherents accept certain ideas as requiring them or encouraging them to observe particular codes of conduct or specific practices having some supernatural significance; (iv) The adherents themselves form an identifiable group or groups; (v) The adherents themselves see the collection of ideas, beliefs and practices as constituting a religion.{{Cite web|url=https://jade.io/article/67076|title=CHURCH OF THE NEW FAITH v. COMMISSIONER OF PAY-ROLL TAX (VICT.) 1983, 154 CLR 120|last=HIGH COURT OF AUSTRALIA|first=|date=27 October 1983|website=Jade|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=8 July 2018}}
In this judgement Section 116 was interpreted more broadly than in previous cases. The justices argued that Section 116 provides fundamental guarantees to freedom of religion:
The development of the law towards complete religious liberty and religious equality... would be subverted and the guarantees in s. 116 of the Constitution would lose their character as a bastion of freedom if religion were so defined as to exclude from its ambit minority religions out of the main streams of religious thought.
=== Adelaide Co of Jehovah's Witnesses Inc v Commonwealth === {{See also|Adelaide Co of Jehovah's Witnesses Inc v Commonwealth}} In the 1941 the Commonwealth Government declared [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] to be a risk to national security, indicating they were believed to be "prejudicial to the defence of the Commonwealth" and the "efficient prosecution of the [[World War II|war]]" due to their following ideals of another Kingdom.{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/legislating-religious-freedom-will-be-a-minefield-for-morrison-20181002-p50798.html|title=Legislating religious freedom will be a minefield for Morrison|last=Hull|first=Crispin|date=2018-10-05|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}} Police occupied premises of the religious group, prompting a lawsuit heard by the High Court in which Jehovah's Witnesses argued their rights granted under Section 116 of the Constitution were infringed.{{Cite web|url=https://lawandreligionaustralia.blog/tag/jehovahs-witness-case/|title=Jehovah’s Witness case – Law and Religion Australia|website=lawandreligionaustralia.blog|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}} The court held that the ''National Security (Subversive Organisations) Regulations'' 1940, under which the Government had taken action, did not infringe against Section 116, but that the government had exceeded their "defence power" in [[Section 51(vi) of the Australian Constitution|section 51(vi)]] of the Constitution. Jehovah's Witnesses have since continued to practice in Australia unabated.{{Cite journal|last=McLeish|first=Stephen|date=1992|title=MAKING SENSE OF RELIGION AND THE CONSTITUTION: A FRESH START FOR SECTION 116|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/journals/MonashULawRw/1992/10.pdf|journal=Monash University Law Review|volume=|pages=207-236|via=}} == Criticism and status quo == The absence of a Federal [[Bill of rights|Bill of Rights]] (or Human Rights Act) which provide a guarantee of religious and other freedoms in almost all other western democracies, has been noted as a primary failure to solidify the current ''de facto'' and ''de jure'' rights to freedom of religion in Australia.{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/comment-australia-needs-a-bill-of-rights|title=Comment: Australia needs a Bill of Rights|work=SBS News|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en-GB}} The [[Australian Human Rights Commission]] has criticised the lack of protections for religious freedom alongside other ''de facto'' freedoms and has recommended the introduction of a Bill of Rights to formally protect the rights of people.{{Cite web|url=https://www.humanrights.gov.au/freedom-thought-conscience-and-religion-or-belief|title=Freedom of thought, conscience and religion or belief|last=David.Mason|date=2013-05-01|website=www.humanrights.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}} Others have highlighted that religion and religious freedoms are already well-protected, including with exemptions to anti-discrimination legislation. Frequently highlighted examples include [[religious school]]s having rights not extended to other institutions, including the ability to fire teachers who do not align with the institution's religious beliefs for any reason. This occurred in the case of the Perth South Coast Baptist College and teacher Craig Campbell who was sacked for coming out as homosexual in 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://www.news.com.au/national/western-australia/mocked-in-class-this-teacher-revealed-he-was-gay-he-lost-his-job/news-story/c1209c28127019613da5cc7ddfe4d700|title=Perth teacher loses his job after telling school he is gay|work=NewsComAu|access-date=2018-06-22}} == Ruddock Review == [[File:Philip Ruddock.jpg|left|thumb|Philip Ruddock, chair of the Religious Freedom Review]] === Report commission === Following the passage of [[same-sex marriage]] [[Same-sex marriage in Australia|legislation in Australia]] in 2017, a federal review was commissioned by the [[Second Turnbull Ministry|Turnbull Government]] to examine the suitability of current religious freedom protections, specifically within the context of the new [[Marriage Amendment (Definition and Religious Freedoms) Act 2017]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.pmc.gov.au/domestic-policy/religious-freedom-review|title=Religious Freedom Review|last=Cabinet|first=Prime Minister and|date=2017-12-12|website=www.pmc.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}} The Religious Freedom Review was chaired by [[Philip Ruddock]], the former [[Attorney-General for Australia]] at the time same-sex marriage was [[Marriage Amendment Act 2004|banned]] by the [[Third Howard Ministry|Howard Government]] in 2004, and had no associated terms of reference.{{Cite web|url=https://www.canberratimes.com.au/national/act/ruddock-review-next-big-battle-for-gay-community-lgbtiq-council-chair-says-20171208-h01e6t.html|title=Ruddock review next big battle for gay community, LGBTIQ council chair says|last=Burgess|first=Katie|website=Canberra Times|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-22}} The review panel was composed of Ruddock alongside [[Jesuit]] priest [[Frank Brennan (priest)|Frank Brennan]], former judge [[Annabelle Bennett]], Human Rights Commission president [[Ros Croucher]] and constitutional lawyer Nicholas Aroney. The expert review panel first met on 10 January 2018, and on 18 May the final review was handed to the Turnbull Government. The Government has declined to release the review in full pending cabinet discussion on its recommendations.{{Cite news|url=http://junkee.com/ruddock-religious-freedom-review/159126|title=The Government Has Received The "Religious Freedom" Report, But We Can't See It|date=2018-05-18|work=Junkee|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en-US}} The Ruddock review has been interpreted as a way to allow the speedy passage of Dean Smith's marriage bill and to postpone discussions of religious freedom.{{cite news|last1=Koziol|first1=Michael|title=Philip Ruddock review into religious freedom fails to deter conservative MPs from attack on marriage bill|url=https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/philip-ruddock-review-into-religious-freedom-fails-to-deter-conservative-mps-from-attack-on-marriage-bill-20171122-gzqbt2.html|accessdate=11 March 2018|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=22 November 2017|language=en}} Proponents of the Ruddock Review argue it is necessary to ensure that religious freedoms are upheld in the wake of religious objection to same-sex marriage, whilst opponents highlight that further protections for religion are not necessary and will occur at the expense of an individual's right to be free from discrimination (particularly in the case of same-sex marriages).{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/don-t-change-discrimination-laws-architect-tells-religious-freedom-review-20180330-p4z74c.html|title=Don't change discrimination laws, architect tells religious freedom review|last=Koziol|first=Michael|date=2018-03-30|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}} Groups such as the [[Victorian Aids Council]] and Australian Human Rights Commission have argued that a comprehensive Bill of Rights -rather than an exclusive religious freedoms law- should be implemented as this would also give full effect to Australia's obligations and commitments under the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] by enshrining all fundamental rights. === Government response === Turnbull's government indicated it would not release the report received in May 2018 until it had been considered in full by the government.{{Cite news|url=https://junkee.com/ruddock-religious-freedom-review/159126|title=The Government Has Received The "Religious Freedom" Report, But We Can't See It|date=2018-05-18|work=Junkee|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en-US}} Following the deposition of Malcolm Turnbull as Prime Minister, his replacement [[Scott Morrison]] indicated his government would not release the report or form a full response to it before the end of 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/oct/11/morrison-eyes-law-to-protect-religion-as-greens-call-for-exemption-rollback|title=Morrison eyes law to protect religion as Greens call for exemption rollback|last=Karp|first=Paul|date=2018-10-11|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-16}} This drew criticism from [[Michael Kirby (judge)|Michael Kirby]] and [[Kerryn Phelps]] given the timing of the [[Wentworth by-election, 2018|Wentworth by-election]], as voters would not have an understanding of any changes to religious law potentially instituted by Australia's first [[Pentecostalism|Pentecostal]] Prime Minister.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/oct/04/michael-kirby-attacks-coalition-for-failure-to-release-ruddock-religious-freedom-report|title=Michael Kirby attacks Coalition for failure to release Ruddock religious freedom report|last=Karp|first=Paul|date=2018-10-04|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-16}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/sep/26/kerryn-phelps-urges-pm-to-release-ruddock-religious-freedom-review-before-byelection|title=Kerryn Phelps urges PM to release Ruddock religious freedom review before byelection|last=Murphy|first=Katharine|date=2018-09-25|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-16}} Despite a senate motion ordering its release ahead of the by-election, the government refused to comply, claiming that a release would "harm the public interest" and interfere in cabinet consideration.{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/release-religious-freedom-report-senators|title=Release religious freedom report: senators|work=SBS News|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.outinperth.com/morrison-government-refuses-release-religious-freedom-report/|title=Morrison government refuses to release religious freedom report {{!}} OUTInPerth – LGBTIQ News and Culture|website=www.outinperth.com|access-date=2018-10-16}} The Prime Minister [[Scott Morrison]] suggested in an [[ABC Radio National|ABC Radio]] interview that the Ruddock review had recommended that people of different religions have the same protections as other attributes such as gender and race.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/oct/11/morrison-eyes-law-to-protect-religion-as-greens-call-for-exemption-rollback|title=Morrison eyes law to protect religion as Greens call for exemption rollback|last=Karp|first=Paul|date=2018-10-11|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-16}} === Leaks and media coverage === On 9 October 2018, extracts of the review were leaked to [[Fairfax Media]], which reported that schools affiliated with a religion "would be guaranteed the right to turn away gay students and teachers under changes to federal anti-discrimination laws" recommended by the review.{{cite news |last1=Topsfield |first1=Jewel |title=Religious freedom review enshrines right of schools to turn away gay children and teachers |url=https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/religious-freedom-review-enshrines-right-of-schools-to-turn-away-gay-children-and-teachers-20181009-p508o7.html |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=9 October 2018 |language=en}} The Prime Minister initially defended this, but stated that the media coverage of the leaked report was "confused".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/oct/10/gay-students-could-be-rejected-by-religious-schools-under-new-laws-report-claims|title=Gay students could be rejected by religious schools under new laws, report claims|last1=Karp|first1=Paul|date=9 October 2018|work=the Guardian|accessdate=12 October 2018|language=en}} Religious schools have held the right to discriminate against teachers and students on the basis of their gender or sexual orientation since 2013, however the Ruddock report recommended that schools additionally be required to hold a publicly-available policy and put the best interests of the child first.{{cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/ruddock-report-constrains-not-expands-federal-religious-exemptions-96347|title=Ruddock report constrains, not expands, federal religious exemptions|last1=Elphick|first1=Liam|last2=Maguire|first2=Amy|date=11 October 2018|website=The Conversation|language=en|accessdate=12 October 2018|last3=Hilkemeijer|first3=Anja}} Following further media coverage and public pressure, the Labor opposition announced their support would be lent to the government should it seek to repeal the discrimination law exemptions already in existence which allow religious schools to ban students based on their sexuality.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/oct/12/labor-offers-support-if-morrison-acts-to-stop-schools-from-expelling-gay-students|title=Labor offers support if Morrison acts to stop schools from expelling gay students|last=Karp|first=Paul|date=2018-10-12|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-16}} The [[Morrison Government]] subsequently agreed to introduce a bill to parliament with that aim.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/oct/13/morrison-caves-to-labor-on-gay-students-in-discrimination-law-reform-push|title=Scott Morrison will change the law to ban religious schools expelling gay students|last=Karp|first=Paul|date=2018-10-12|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-16}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.theage.com.au/national/bipartisan-backflip-on-queer-bigotry-20181013-p509hr.html|title=Bipartisan backflip on queer bigotry|date=2018-10-13|website=The Age|language=en|access-date=2018-10-16}} The [[Australian Greens]] and Labor opposition have further committed to revoking discrimination exemptions that also allow discrimination against teachers based on their sexual orientation, however the government has so far not indicated its position.{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/protect-gay-teachers-now-labor|title=Protect gay teachers now: Labor|work=SBS News|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en-GB}} The full recommendations of the review were subsequently leaked to Fairfax and reported on 12 October 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/read-the-full-20-recommendations-from-the-religious-freedom-review-20181011-p50918.html|title=Read the full 20 recommendations from the religious freedom review|date=2018-10-11|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-10-16}} == See also == *[[Section 116 of the Constitution of Australia]] *[[Religion in Australia]] * [[Australian Bill of Rights Group]] ==References== {{Reflist}}{{Religion in Australia}} [[Category:Australia]] [[Category:Rights]] [[Category:Constitution of Australia]] [[Category:Politics of Australia]] [[Category:Religion in Australia]]

([[Master of Arts (Scotland)|M.A.]], 1950)
[[University of London]]
(doctorate, 1957) |profession = [[Professor]] |religion = [[Islam]][[#Shu84|Shukri 1984]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=xF5mAAAAMAAJ&q=Hikmat+Zaid p. 31] |signature = |signature_alt = |allegiance = [[Egypt]] |battles = [[Suez Crisis|Suez War]] }} '''Hikmat Abu Zayd''' ({{Lang-ar|حكمت أبو زيد}}; pronounced '''Hekmat Abu Zeid''' in [[Egyptian Arabic]]; 1922 or 1923 – 30 July 2011){{ref label|Birth|N|2}}[http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/17747/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-first-female-minister-dies-at-.aspx Egypt's first female minister dies at 96] ''Ahram Online'', 31 July 2011 was an Egyptian politician and academic. She became the first female cabinet minister in Egypt in 1962.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sis.gov.eg/En/Story.aspx?sid=2259|title=Women in the Executive Authority|publisher=Egypt State Information Service|accessdate=27 February 2011}} Her tenure as minister of social affairs set a precedent. Afterwards, it became common for women to head that ministry. An avowed advocate of [[Nasserism]],[[#Gol00|Goldschmidt 2000]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=p3J6IS8t74QC&pg=PA14 p. 14] Abu Zayd has had a major impact on Egyptian law and policy in the areas of [[Social work|social affairs]] and [[Social insurance|insurance]].[[#Sul86|Sullivan 1986]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y900ymkaKX4C&pg=PA69 p. 69] ==Early life and education== Born in the village of Shaykh Daud, located near the city of [[Cusae|al-Qusiyya]] in [[Asyut Governorate]], Abu Zayd grew up in a [[Egyptian nationalism|nationalist]] household. Her father's job at the [[Egyptian National Railways|Egyptian State Railways]] meant that he was assigned to many stations and was constantly on the move. Although her mother was illiterate, Abu Zayd was encouraged to read and was given access to her father's large library. Abu Zayd received an advanced education. After completing her [[secondary education]] at the Helwan Girls School, she obtained a [[Licentiate (degree)|licence]] in history from [[Cairo University]] (then named Fuad I University) in 1940. She progressed further in her academic studies by receiving a teaching certificate in 1941, a [[Master of Arts]] in education in 1950 from the [[University of St Andrews]], and finally a [[doctorate]] in [[educational psychology]] from the [[University of London]] in 1957. She taught in the Women's College of [[Ain Shams University]] from 1955 to 1964, before being promoted to the rank of [[Professor#Egypt|professor]] at Cairo University in 1965. ==Tenure as minister== In 1962, Abu Zayd sat on the preparatory committee for the [[National Congress of Popular Forces]]. During her membership of the committee, she expressed her disagreement with [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] over some sections in the [[Charter of National Action]]. Impressed, Nasser decided to appoint her as a minister.{{Cite journal|last=Turki|first=Sayyed|date=8 December 2010|title=الوزيرة حكمت قلب الثورة الرحيم|trans-title=Minister Hikmat, the Merciful Heart of the Revolution|journal=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|issue=2369|language=Arabic|accessdate=27 February 2011|url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=280253|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707115053/http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=280253|archivedate=7 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} On 29 September 1962, Abu Zayd was named minister of social affairs in [[Ali Sabri]]'s first government.{{Cite web |url=http://modernegypt.bibalex.org/TxtViewer/TextViewer.aspx?ID=23739&type=Document |title=Presidential Decree Appointing Hikmat Abu Zayd as Minister of Social Affairs in Ali Sabri's First Government|date=29 September 1962 |work=Memory of Modern Egypt Digital Archive|publisher=[[Bibliotheca Alexandrina]]|language=Arabic|accessdate=27 February 2011}} She retained her role when the cabinet was reshuffled in March 1964,{{Cite web |url=http://modernegypt.bibalex.org/TxtViewer/TextViewer.aspx?ID=23740&type=Document|title=Presidential Decree Appointing Hikmat Abu Zayd as Minister of Social Affairs in Ali Sabri's Second Government |date=25 March 1964|work=Memory of Modern Egypt Digital Archive |publisher=[[Bibliotheca Alexandrina]]|language=Arabic|accessdate=27 February 2011}} and served until 1965.[[#Sul86|Sullivan 1986]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y900ymkaKX4C&pg=PA173 p. 173] Abu Zayd was part of a new female leadership that shared the same [[lower middle class]] background of Nasser and his fellow [[Free Officers Movement (Egypt)|Free Officers]].[[#Tal96|Talhami 1996]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=1vjXmi5emY4C&pg=PA19 pp. 19–20] Her appointment by Nasser was made in the context of his new socialist program, which put emphasis on broadening access to education and employment for all people, regardless of gender or social class.[[#Bad96|Badran 1996]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=Vrw8WGOmscAC&pg=PA188 p. 188] The 1950s and especially the 1960s were a time of increased female emancipation in Egypt.[[#Sul86|Sullivan 1986]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y900ymkaKX4C&pg=PA80 p. 80] [[Polygyny]] was on the decline, and women were increasingly holding key posts in government, industry and academia.{{Cite news |title=Egypt's Women Most Emancipated in Region |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DJMtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CZ4FAAAAIBAJ&pg=7248,4152464|agency=[[Reuters]]|newspaper=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]]|date=21 October 1963|page=10|accessdate=27 February 2011}} The country's first two female parliamentarians, [[Rawya Ateya]] and [[Amina Shukri]], were elected in 1957.[[#Sul86|Sullivan 1986]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y900ymkaKX4C&pg=PA39 p. 39] [[Karimah al-Sa'id]] became the deputy minister of education in the 1960s. Such high-level appointments of a few well-qualified women were showcased by the government, while the majority of Egyptian women remained stuck in the lower echelons of society. Nasser's appointment of Abu Zayd was a politically significant move. Including a woman in the cabinet was a way for him to co-opt female-run charitable organizations into the [[Arab Socialist Union (Egypt)|Arab Socialist Union]] (ASU), the country's newly formed [[One-party state|sole political party]].[[#Rus04|Russell 2004]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=NDEOAQAAMAAJ&q=co-opt p. 39] Many of these associations were headed by women from prominent families and were protective of their independence, which Nasser found objectionable. His regime targeted women's organizations in the early 1960s and moved to take over most of their functions as state responsibilities, thereby depriving the associations of their momentum and autonomy. Abu Zayd implemented these policies, which were aimed at benefiting female workers and peasants.[[#Sul86|Sullivan 1986]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y900ymkaKX4C&pg=PA81 p. 81] The Ministry of Social Affairs which she headed was increasingly specializing in women's issues. In 1963, it organized a general and wide-ranging women's conference to discuss, among other things, ways to increase female economic [[productivity]], working women's leading role in spreading [[family planning]], as well as the rise of family income through the employment of female members. Abu Zayd was named to preside over the conference, thereby cementing her status as leader of the [[Feminism in Egypt|women's movement in Egypt]]. She became coordinator for women's activities within the Arab Socialist Union in 1963, at a time when the party had nearly 250,000 female members. During her time in office, Abu Zayd worked on several different social issues. She strongly supported a law that prohibited [[Divorce (Islamic)|Islamic oral repudiation]] and made it mandatory for a husband to go to court to be able to divorce his wife.{{Cite news |title=Egypt's Divorce Law May Be Changed |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KGQhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5YYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3989,4125145|agency=[[Associated Press|AP]]|newspaper=[[Tri-City Herald]]|date=29 January 1964|page=20|accessdate=27 February 2011}} In order to combat [[Begging|mendicity]], she imposed prison terms on recidivist beggars who returned to begging after they had received state-sponsored training in handicrafts.{{Cite news |title=Prison Eyed for Beggars |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ltxXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5OgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3156,3756081 |agency=[[Reuters]] |newspaper=[[The Spokesman-Review]]|date=29 November 1964|page=16 |accessdate=27 February 2011}} In addition to registering [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]]s and expanding their development activities, she launched projects aimed at improving the status of rural women. One of the most sensitive tasks assigned to Abu Zayd was the relocation of thousands of [[Nubian people|Nubians]], displaced by the construction of the [[Aswan Dam]], to newly built villages. Her management of the resettlement process led to her being [[nickname]]d the "Merciful Heart of the Revolution" by Nasser. Nevertheless, the Nubians' [[Development-induced displacement|forced displacement]] remains controversial in Egypt to this day, with some blaming Nasser for the neglectful conditions in which the relocated Nubians have been living since then. On a personal level, Abu Zayd faced domestic problems during her tenure as minister. Her husband was resentful of her responsibility-laden role and of the amount of time she spent outside the house. Their previously modest lifestyle changed considerably as she hired a 12-year-old [[houseboy]] and was provided a [[Take-home vehicle|chauffeur-driven car]] by the government.{{Cite news |title=Wife's Job Has Spouse Resentful|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xMAtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Cp4FAAAAIBAJ&pg=6000,3285101 |agency=[[Reuters]]|newspaper=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]]|date=16 November 1962|page=9|accessdate=27 February 2011}} ==Exile in Libya== Following Nasser's death in 1970 and [[Anwar Sadat]]'s ascension to the presidency, Abu Zayd's career progression was blocked. She moved to [[Libya]] with her husband in 1974. Her Nasserist convictions were in line with the [[Anti-imperialism|anti-colonialism]], [[anti-Zionism]] and [[pan-Arabism]] of Libya's leader [[Muammar Gaddafi]]. Abu Zayd spent nearly two decades in Libya, during which time she taught [[political science]] at [[Al Fateh University]] in [[Tripoli]]. She also penned articles and made speeches denouncing the Egyptian government. Abu Zayd began criticizing President Sadat in the mid-1970s. She became a leader of the [[Egyptian National Front]], which was set up in [[Damascus]] in 1980 by General [[Saad El Shazly]]. The organization called for the overthrow of Sadat's government.[[#Sul86|Sullivan 1986]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y900ymkaKX4C&pg=PA120 p. 120] Due to her opposition to Sadat's peace overture to [[Israel]], Abu Zayd was accused of [[high treason]], [[terrorism]] and [[spying]], and was consequently deprived of her Egyptian nationality. This turned her into a [[Statelessness|stateless]] political [[refugee]]. A long legal battle ensued, which was finally resolved in late 1991 when a judge ruled that Abu Zayd and her husband were entitled to their [[Egyptian passport]]s. She was also acquitted of the charges of high treason and terrorism. ==Later years and death== After having recovered their nationality, Abu Zayd and her husband came back to Egypt in March 1992. She was treated as a [[Very Important Person|VIP]] upon her return, and rushed to visit Nasser's [[mausoleum]]. During the 1990s, she opposed the [[Gulf War]], the [[Madrid Conference of 1991|Madrid Peace Conference]], as well as Israeli and [[American imperialism]]. She wrote articles for ''[[al-Osboa]]'' newspaper in 1998 dealing with the issues of Western imperialism and Arab unity. In late 2010, she was hospitalized at the Anglo-American Hospital in Cairo to receive treatment for her [[bone fracture]]s.{{Cite journal|last=Noureddine|first=Sarah|date=8 December 2010|title=المصري اليوم حاورتها على فراش المرض حكمت أبوزيد أول وزيرة مصرية: معظم الحركات السياسية الموجودة الآن سطحية.. وتعارض باندفاع غير مسؤول|trans-title=Almasry Alyoum interviewed her on her sickbed – Hikmat Abu Zayd, the first Egyptian female minister: Most current political movements are "superficial" and oppose with an "irresponsible" impulsiveness|journal=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|issue=2369|language=Arabic|accessdate=27 February 2011|url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=280252|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707115102/http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=280252|archivedate=7 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} [[Farkhonda Hassan]] visited her there on behalf of then First Lady [[Suzanne Mubarak]].{{Cite journal|date=6 December 2010|title=قومي المرأة يطمئن على صحة د. حكمت أبوزيد|trans-title=National Council for Women reassured about Dr. Hikmat Abu Zayd's health condition|journal=[[Al Gomhuria]]|language=Arabic|accessdate=27 February 2011|url=http://www.gom.com.eg/index.php?action=news&id=76169|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720131213/http://www.gom.com.eg/index.php?action=news&id=76169|archivedate=20 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} During her stay at the hospital, Abu Zayd granted an interview to ''[[Almasry Alyoum]]'' newspaper in which she defended Nasser's legacy and lamented the loss of tolerance in Egypt. Abu Zayd died in Cairo on 30 July 2011. ==Awards== Abu Zayd received the [[Lenin Peace Prize]] in December 1970.[[#Shu84|Shukri 1984]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=xF5mAAAAMAAJ&q=February+1974 p. 31] ==See also== *[[List of the first female holders of political offices in Africa]] *[[Women in Arab societies]] *[[Women in Egypt]] ==Notes== :'''I'''{{note label|Birth||1}}{{note label|Birth||2}}: According to Arthur Goldschmidt's ''[[#Gol00|Biographical Dictionary of Modern Egypt]]'', Abu Zayd was born in 1922. Sabin M. Shukri's ''[[#Shu84|International Who's Who of the Arab World]]'' gives 1923 as her year of birth. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Bibliography== *{{Cite book |last1=Badran |first1=Margot |title=Feminists, Islam, and Nation: Gender and the Making of Modern Egypt |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vrw8WGOmscAC&printsec=frontcover |year=1996 |publisher=Princeton University Press |isbn=978-0-691-02605-3 |ref=Bad96}} *{{Cite book |last1=Goldschmidt |first1=Arthur |title=Biographical Dictionary of Modern Egypt |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p3J6IS8t74QC&printsec=frontcover |year=2000 |publisher=American University in Cairo Press |isbn=978-977-424-579-4 |ref=Gol00}} *{{Cite encyclopedia |last=Russell |first=Mona |editor=[[Philip Mattar|Mattar, Philip]] |encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of the Modern Middle East & North Africa |title=Abu Zayd, Hikmat |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-3424600056.html |subscription=yes |edition=2nd |year=2004 |publisher=Macmillan Reference USA |volume=Volume 1: Aaronsohn – Cyril VI |location=Detroit, MI |isbn=978-0-02-865770-7 |pages=39–40 |ref=Rus04}} *{{Cite book |isbn=978-0-9506122-1-8 |ref=Shu84}} *{{Cite book |last1=Sullivan |first1=Earl L. |title=Women in Egyptian Public Life |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y900ymkaKX4C&printsec=frontcover {{Orphan|date=February 2009}} The '''income in respect of a decedent (IRD) asset''' is part of [[inheritance]] which consists of [[taxable income]] to which the deceased person was entitled to, but failed to receive before their death. A typical case is the last [[paycheck]], which may be left not received.
Most of [[inheritance|inherited]] [[property]] is not included in an [[heir]]’s taxable income, but IRD assets do.
While the tax basis of most of a decedent's assets are "[[step-up in basis|stepped up]]" for income tax purposes, IRD assets are not eligible for a "step-up" in basis, and hence may lead to [[double taxation]], and an income tax and [[estate tax]].
==External links== *[http://www.leismaninsurance.com/2004%20April%20IRD%20article.html "Income in Respect of a Decedent (IRD)"]
The following are considered IRD Income:
• Uncollected salaries, wages, bonuses, commissions, vacation pay, and sick pay.
• Certain deferred compensation and stock option plans.
• Qualified pension plans, profit sharing plans, SEP, Keogh, and IRA except nondeductible contributions.
• Accounts receivable of a cash basis sole proprietor.
• Interest and dividends accrued but unpaid at death of cash basis decedent.
• Rents and royalties accrued before death of cash basis taxpayer.
• Gain from the sale of property if the sale is deemed to occur before death, but proceeds are not collected until after death.
• Difference between the face amount and the decedent’s basis in an installment sales obligation.
• Interest accrued through the date of death on Series EE bonds, unless (1) decedent elected to report interest annually, or (2) the interest was reported on the decedent’s final Form 1040.
• Annuity payments in excess of decedent's investment in the contract

{{Infobox company | name = Interval Research Corporation | logo = Interval logo.png | caption = | type = Research [[think tank]] | fate = Dissolved | Predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 1992 | defunct = 2000 | location = [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]], [[United States|U.S.]] | industry = Research and Development | products = | key_people = [[Paul Allen]] (Chairman)
[[David Liddle]] (CEO, President) | num_employees = More than 110 | parent = | subsid = }} '''Interval Research Corporation''' was founded in 1992 by [[Paul Allen]] and [[David Liddle]]. It was a [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]] laboratory and [[technology incubator]] focusing on consumer product applications and services with a focus on the Internet.{{cite web| title= WTO Board Bio: David Liddle | url= http://www.stanford.edu/group/WTO/people/board/liddle.shtml | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070311150631/http://www.stanford.edu/group/WTO/people/board/liddle.shtml | archivedate= 2007-03-11}} A 1997 version of the company's web page described itself as ''"a research setting seeking to define the issues, map out the concepts and create the technology that will be important in the future.... [pursuing] basic innovations in a number of early-stage technologies and [seeking] to foster industries around them – sparking opportunity for entrepreneurs and highlighting a new approach to research."''.[https://web.archive.org/web/19971012120741/http://www.interval.com/about/ Interval Research Corporation – About] – Page (From:13-November-1996) A 1999 [[Wired (magazine)|''Wired'' magazine]] article based on a memo from Paul Allen described the company as under fire from Allen to produce "less R and more D."{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/7.12/interval.html|title=Think Tanked|last=Bass|first=Thomas A.|date=Dec 1999|publisher=Wired Magazine|accessdate=20 April 2010}} Interval Research Corporation officially closed its doors in April 2000, while a small group of former employees were kept on to form '''Interval Media''' to continue a few specific projects. Interval Media was closed in June, 2006. ==Former employees== {{more citations needed|list of former employees|date=August 2010}} During its brief existence, Interval employed many well-known computer technology pioneers and experts, including: {{div col}} * [[Denise Caruso]], technology journalist * [[Franklin C. Crow]], inventor of important anti-aliasing techniques * [[Sally Cruikshank]], filmmaker and animator * [[Marc Davis (academic)|Marc Davis]], founder of Yahoo! Research Berkeley * [[Paul Debevec]], computer graphics researcher * [[Bruce Donald]], geometer and animation researcher (computer graphics), co-inventor (with [[Tom Ngo]]) of [[Embedded Constraint Graphics]][http://www.cs.duke.edu/brd/Patents/ngo-donald99.pdf System for Image Manipulation and Animation Using Embedded Constraint Graphics. J. T. Ngo and B. R. Donald. U.S. Patent #5,933,150, issued August 3, 1999.][https://www.cs.duke.edu/brd/papers/src-papers/Siggraph2000/ngo-donald-siggraph2000.pdf Accessible Animation and Customizable Graphics via Simplicial Configuration Modeling. T. Ngo, D. Cutrell, J. Dana, B. R. Donald, L. Loeb, and S. Zhu. Proc. ACM SIGGRAPH (New Orleans) July, 2000, pp. 403–410.] * Glenn Edens, founder of [[Grid Systems Corporation]], which made the first laptop computer * [[Caterina Fake]], co-founder of [[Flickr]] and [[Hunch (website)|Hunch]] * [[Rolf Faste]], Stanford design professor, who led the team that named the corporation "Interval Research" * [[Lee Felsenstein]], designer of the first mass-produced portable computer * [[Paul Freiberger]], Silicon Valley journalist * [[Don Hopkins]], new-media artist, [[The Sims]] developer and [[pie menu]] interface designer * [[Brenda Laurel]], author, entrepreneur, virtual-reality artist * [[Golan Levin]], new-media artist * [[Daniel Levitin]], cognitive neuroscientist, best-selling author * David Levitt, virtual reality pioneer, creator of Pantomime VR platform * [[David Liddle]], venture capitalist * [[Max Mathews]], acoustician, computer music pioneer * [[Michael Naimark]], new-media artist * [[Tom Ngo]], animation researcher (computer graphics), co-inventor (with [[Bruce Donald]]) of [[Embedded Constraint Graphics]] * [[John R. Pierce]], electrical engineer, inventor of satellite telecommunication and the travelling wave tube * [[David P. Reed]], inventor of TCP/IP * [[Robert Shaw (physicist)|Robert Shaw]], physicist and chaos theory pioneer * Richard Shoup, creator of [[SuperPaint]] * [[Malcolm Slaney]], research scientist at [[Google]], [[IEEE Fellow]] * [[Gillian Crampton Smith]], founder of the [[Interaction Design Institute Ivrea]] in [[Ivrea]], Italy and the [[Computer-Related Design]] program at the [[Royal College of Art]] * [[Scott Snibbe]], new-media artist * [[Bill Verplank]], interface designer of the [[Xerox Star]], the first [[WIMP (computing)]] GUI * [[Leo Villareal]], installation artist and [[Burning Man]] board memberhttp://burningman.org/network/about-us/people/board-of-directors/#LeoVillareal * [[Terry Winograd]], emeritus professor of computer science at [[Stanford University]] *[[Dan Ingalls]], inventor of BitBLT and architect of several [[Smalltalk]] implementations * [[Tim Rowledge]], designer, software engineer, [[Smalltalk]]er,http://www.rowledge.org/tim/squeak/index.html author http://sdmeta.gforge.inria.fr/FreeBooks/CollectiveNBlueBook/Rowledge-Final.pdf originating student of the [[Computer-Related Design]] program at the [[Royal College of Art]] {{div col end}} ==Patents== Interval Research was issued approximately 130 US patents.[http://www.ipexl.com/share/0ca3c0cd396017b2b639df1dfae319fe Interval Research's List of US Patents] Four of its patents, [[Patent holding company|now owned]] by Allen's Interval Licensing LLC, are the subject of a [[patent infringement]] lawsuit Interval Licensing filed in August 2010 against [[AOL]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[eBay]], [[Facebook]], [[Google]], [[Netflix]], [[Office Depot]], [[OfficeMax]], [[Staples Inc.|Staples]], [[Yahoo!]], and [[YouTube]] (but not Microsoft): *{{patent|US|6034652}}: "Attention manager for occupying the peripheral attention of a person in the vicinity of a display device". [http://see-the-forest.com/DocumentRecall.act?docId=1nsdji.gdf61tqth&orgId=fts View Patent Landscape Map]. *{{patent|US|6788314}}: "Attention manager for occupying the peripheral attention of a person in the vicinity of a display device (continuation)". [http://see-the-forest.com/DocumentRecall.act?docId=1nsdji.gdf65jah5&orgId=fts View Patent Landscape Map]. *{{patent|US|6263507}}: "Browser for use in navigating a body of information, with particular application to browsing information represented by audiovisual data". [http://see-the-forest.com/DocumentRecall.act?docId=1nsdji.gdf5qvvrk&orgId=fts View Patent Landscape Map]. *{{patent|US|6757682}}: "Alerting users to items of current interest". [http://see-the-forest.com/DocumentRecall.act?docId=1nsdji.gdf69dtpw&orgId=fts View Patent Landscape Map]. The lawsuit also points out that Interval Research was credited by Google in 1998 as an "outside collaborator" and one of the companies that funded research by Sergey Brin and Lawrence Page that resulted in Google. On Mar. 3, 2011, [[Article One Partners]] announced that one of the patents held by Interval Licensing would be posted to their online community to utilize [[Public participation in patent examination]]. The patent in question was [http://www.google.com/patents?id=NbgIAAAAEBAJ&printsec=abstract&zoom=4&source=gbs_overview_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false U.S. Patent No. 6,263,507], defined as "Browser for Use in Navigating a Body of Information, With Particular Application to Browsing Information Represented By Audiovisual Data."[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/article-one-partners-launches-public-review-of-interval-licensing-llc-patent-asserted-against-technology-industry-leaders-117311008.html "Article One Partners Launches Public Review of Interval Licensing LLC Patent Asserted Against Technology Industry Leaders"] ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web| title= Microsoft Co-Founder Launches Patent War | url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703294904575385241453119382 | date=August 28, 2010 | publisher= [[The Wall Street Journal]] | first= Dionne | last= Searcey |accessdate=2010-08-28}} {{cite web| title= Interval Licensing LLC v. AOL Inc. et al. | url= https://online.wsj.com/public/resources/documents/intervallicensingcomplaint0827.pdf | date=August 27, 2010 | work= Complaint for Patent Infringement | publisher= [[The Wall Street Journal]] | accessdate=2010-08-28}} }} ==External links== *[https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/7.12/interval.html Think Tanked] ''Wired'' magazine, December 1999 {{US Business Incubators}} [[Category:Companies based in Palo Alto, California]] [[Category:Technology companies established in 1992]] [[Category:Technology companies disestablished in 2000]] [[Category:Defunct companies based in California]] [[Category:Business incubators of the United States]] [[Category:Legal disputes]] [[Category:Patent monetization companies of the United States]]

The parchment codex called '''''Littera Florentina''''' is the closest survivor to an official version of the [[Pandects]], the digest of [[Roman law]] promulgated by [[Justinian I]] in 530–533.
The codex, of 907 leaves, is written in the Byzantine-Ravenna [[uncial]]s characteristic of [[Constantinople]], but which has recently been recognized in legal and literary texts produced in Alexandria and the Levant as well. [[Elias Avery Lowe|E.A. Lowe]] refers to this script as "b-r uncial". Close scrutiny dates the manuscript between the official issuance in 533 and the issuance of 557 that included Justinian's recent enactments, the ''[[Novellae Constitutiones]]'', "New Constitutions", making it an all-but contemporary and all-but official source.
Marginal notes suggest that the codex was in [[Amalfi]]—part of the Byzantine territory in Italy governed by the [[Exarchate of Ravenna]] in the 6th century—and that it passed to [[Pisa]] in the 12th century; thus, during the Middle Ages the codex was known as the ''Littera Pisana'',<ref>Michael J. Hoeflich and Jasonne M. Grabher, "The establishment of normative legal texts: the beginnings of the ''Ius communis''", in Wilfried Hartmann and Kenneth Pennington, eds. ''The history of medieval Canon law in the Classical period, 1140-1234'', 2008:5 and note 21.</ref> until the codex formed part of the war booty removed from Pisa to Florence after the war of 1406.
The manuscript became one of Florence's most treasured possessions. It was only shown to very important persons. Scholarly access was difficult. It took more than three centuries before a reliable edition of the ''Littera Florentina'' was finally made available. Nowadays two facsimile editions are at the disposal of scholars.<ref>''Iustiniani Augusti Digestorum seu Pandectarum Codex Florentinus olim Pisanus phototypice expressus'', I-X, (Rome, 1902-1910). ''Justiniani Augusti pandectarum codex Florentinus'', Curaverunt A. Corbino & B. Santalucia, (Firenze: Olschki, 1988).</ref>
The importance of the manuscript lies in the fact that is an almost unique witness of the original Justinianian Digest. Most medieval manuscripts of the Digest have a substantially different text. Its sudden reappearance in the late eleventh or early twelfth century has been much debated by legal historians.
==Notes== {{reflist|2}} Enrico Spagnesi, ''Le Pandette di Giustiniano: storia e fortuna della 'Littera Florentina': mostra di codici documenti,'' (exhibition catalogue) June-August 1983 (Florence: Olschki) 1983.
== See also == * ''[[Corpus Juris Civilis]]'' * [[Byzantine law]] * [[Glossator]]s * [[Roman Law]]
== External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070310140926/http://www.archaeogate.org/iura/article/199/1/la-littera-florentina-di-gianfranco-purpura.html Gianfranco Purpura, "La Littera Florentina"] (in Italian) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120831060912/http://web.upmf-grenoble.fr/Haiti/Cours/Ak/ ''The Roman Law Library'' by Professor Yves Lassard and Alexandr Koptev] *[http://www.law.berkeley.edu/library/robbins/RomanLegalTradition.html Discussion of the place of the Littera Florentina within Roman legal tradition] *[http://www.law.berkeley.edu/library/robbins/pdf/RomanLegalTradition.pdf Pdf including illustrations of the Littera Florentina] {{Italic title}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:6th-century Latin books]] [[Category:Law books]] [[Category:Byzantine law]] [[Category:Latin prose texts]] [[Category:Roman law]] [[Category:6th-century manuscripts]] [[Category:Justinian I]]

{{Infobox legislation |long_title = An Act to provide National Defense of the Philippines, penalizing certain violations thereof, appropriating funds therefor, and for other purposes |citation = [http://www.gov.ph/1935/12/21/commonwealth-act-no-1/ Commonwealth Act No. 1] |territorial_extent = [[Philippines]] |legislature = |enacted_by = [[National Assembly of the Philippines]] |date_enacted = December 21, 1935 |enacted_by2 = |date_enacted2 = |date_signed = December 21, 1935 |signed_by = [[Manuel L. Quezon]] |date_commenced = |bill_date = |introduced_by = |1st_reading = |2nd_reading = |3rd_reading = |conf_committee_passed = |bill2 = |bill_citation2 = |bill_date2 = |introduced_by2 = |1st_reading2 = |2nd_reading2 = |3rd_reading2 = |conf_committee_passed2 = |date_conf_committee = |committee_report = |amendments = |repeals = |related_legislation = |summary = |keywords = [[Military]], [[national security]] |status = In force }} '''The National Defense Act of 1935''' ('''Commonwealth Act № 1''') was passed by the [[Philippine National Assembly]] on December 21, 1935. The purpose of this act was to create an independent [[Armed Forces of the Philippines|Philippine Army]], a move interrupted by the outbreak of the [[Second World War]].
==Provisions== This act provided for the creation, by 1946, via an annual [[Appropriation (Law)|appropriation]] of 16,000,000 [[Philippine peso|pesos]], of the following forces:
*A [[regular army]] force of 10,000 troops (formed largely from the [[Philippine Scouts]] and the [[Philippine Constabulary]]) *A [[reserve army]] of 400,000 *The [[Offshore Patrol]], which was to possess 36 [[torpedo boat]]s *A [[Philippine Army Air Corps]] of 100 [[tactical bomber]]s
==Office of the Military Advisor== The National Assembly was guided by the [[Office of the Military Advisor to the Commonwealth Government (Philippines)|Office of the Military Advisor to the Commonwealth Government]] under the [[United States|U.S.]] [[General]] [[Douglas MacArthur]].
==Military Districts== The act divided the [[Commonwealth of the Philippines]] into ten [[Military district|military districts]], similar to the prewar [[Corps area|corps areas]] within the [[United States|US]]. Each district had a roughly equal population and each was to initially provide 1 reserve [[Division (military)|division]], and ultimately three.
*[[Luzon]], [[Mindoro]], [[Palawan]], and [[Masbate]] contained 5 military districts *[[Mindanao]] and the [[Sulu Archipelago]] constituted 1 district *The [[Visayas]] contained 4 districts
==Reserve Training== The Act provided for the [[Conscription in the Philippines|drafting]] of Filipino men, between the ages of 21 and 50, into the 30 reserve divisions. This force was to be raised through 2 training camps, of 20,000 men each, lasting 22 weeks. The camps would be staffed by members of the regular army.
The first group of 20,000 troops was drafted on January 1, 1937, and there were 4,800 [[commissioned officer|officers]] and 104,000 enlisted men in the reserves by 1939.
==Officer Training== For the training of junior officers, the Act provided that a military academy be established with a [[Cadet Corps]] strength not to exceed 350 at any one time. As graduates could not be expected until they had completed 4 years of training, selected reservists were selected for training as [[noncommissioned officer]]s. The best of these were then given basic office training and commissioned as [[Lieutenant|3rd Lieutenant]]s. Officers were also created through senior-level [[ROTC]] courses in [[college]]s and [[university|universities]].
==Training Locations== *[[Infantry]] training—various locations *[[artillery|Field Artillery]] training—Fort Dau and specialized training conducted at [[Fort William McKinley]] *[[artillery|Coastal Artillery]] training -- [[Fort Mills]], [[Fort Stotsenburg]], and [[Fort Wint]] *signal and medical training -- [[Fort William McKinley]] *quartermaster motor transport school—port area of [[Manila]] *government organizational training—various locations
==External links== *[http://www.chanrobles.com/commonwealthacts/commonwealthactno1.html The National Defense Act of 1935]
==See also== *[[Military History of the Philippines]] *[[Military History of the United States]]

Chief National Librarian | num_employees =~178 | phone_num = | website ={{URL|http://www.nlp.gov.pk/index.html}} | references = }} The '''National Library of Pakistan''' ([[Urdu]]:{{Nastaliq|قومى کتب خانہ پاکستان}}), is the [[National library|national]] and the [[Research library|research]] library located in the vicinity of the [[Constitution Avenue (Islamabad)|Constitutional Avenue]], [[Islamabad]], [[Pakistan]]. [[Americans|American]] author, Stuart Murray, argues that it is the oldest cultural institutional that plays a leading role in providing the resource for [[Information science|information]]— ancient and new.{{cite book|last1=Murray|first1=Stuart|title=Library : an illustrated history.|date=2012|publisher=W W Norton|location=New York|isbn=9781616084530|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HMgtAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT462 |accessdate=20 August 2014|language=|format=google books|chapter=National Library of Pakistan}} Established in 1951, it was originally housed in the secretariat of [[Ministry of Education (Pakistan)|Ministry of Education]] (MoEd) and amalgamated with the [[Liaquat National Memorial Library|Liaquat National Library]] (LNL); it was shifting in [[Islamabad]] in 1965 with [[Ministry of Education (Pakistan)|MoEd]]'s secretariat serving its purpose.{{cite web|last1=et. al.|title=History of the National Library|url=http://www.nlp.gov.pk/about_nlp.html|publisher=National Library of Pakistan Press, History|accessdate=20 August 2014}} In 1962, the Library received the right of transference of all [[copyrighted]] works to have two copies deposited of [[book]]s, [[map]]s, [[illustration]]s and [[diagram]]s printed in Pakistan. It gained more significance in 1992 with the promulgation of copyright (amendment) act 1992. During the [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1971|1971 war]], the library was thinned with the creation of [[Bangladesh]] with key material transferring to [[Bangladesh]].{{cite book |chapter=Supplement 7|title=International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science |editor-first=John |editor-last=Feather |editor-first2=Paul |editor-last2=Sturges |date=1987|publisher=Dekker|location=New York |isbn=0824720423|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JD0vL9QQT0sC&pg=PA596}} After a period of slow growth in its reconstruction, the library began to enlarge its size and importance in the country. Development culminated in 1980s of an expensive and separated national library building within the vicinity of the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan library|Supreme Court's library]].{{cite web|title=Address and location of the National Library of Pakistan|url=https://www.google.com/maps/@33.726249,73.10195,17z|publisher=google maps services|accessdate=20 August 2014}} Designed with [[Eastern architectures|Eastern]] [[architecture]], the library has space for 500 readers as well as 15 research rooms, a 450-seat auditorium, and computer and microfilm services. At its opening in 1993, the library owned a collection of 130,000 volumes and 600 manuscripts. Clauses to include electronic publications, as deposit material, are also being added to the Copyright law.Muhammad Waris, Bhatti. 2014. "National Library of Pakistan as Legal Depository." ''Pakistan Library & Information Science Journal'' 45, no. 1: 18-23. The national library mission to promote [[literacy]] as well serving as a dynamic cultural and educational center for the [[State capital|state's capital]]– the [[Islamabad]]. == History == Authorization for a national library can be traced back to 1949, although it did not gain any physical infrastructure until it was merged with the existing Liaquat Memorial Library in Karachi and renamed the Liaquat National Library. In 1967 the library began receiving copies of works published in Pakistan as part of its mandate as a copyright repository per the 1962 copyright ordinance. 1968 saw the separation of the Liaquat and National libraries, with the latter relocated to Islamabad along with Pakistan's capitol. The library was housed in a series of rented structures until construction of a permanent building was completed in 1988. The formal opening took place on 24 August 1993. Scholar Syed Jalaluddin Haider dates the library's existence later, to April 1999, when the 100,000-volume collection housed by the Department of Libraries was moved into the new building. == See also == * [[List of libraries]] == References == {{reflist | refs= {{cite journal | first1=Pervaiz | last1=Ahmad | title=The National Library of Pakistan: an overview | year=2007 | pages=90–98 | journal=IFLA Journal | volume=34 | number=1 | url=http://archive.ifla.org/V/iflaj/IFLA-Journal-1-2008.pdf | publisher=SAGE | ISSN=0340-0352 | doi=10.1177/0340035208088578 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20140807192014/http%3A//archive.ifla.org/V/iflaj/IFLA%2DJournal%2D1%2D2008.pdf | archivedate=2014-08-07 | df= }} {{cite book | page=645–646 | title=World Encyclopedia of Library and Information Services | year=1993 | ISBN=0-8389-0609-5 | publisher=American Library Association | edition=3rd | editor-last=Wedgeworth | editor-first=Robert | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HSFu99FCJwQC&pg=645}} {{cite book | page=596 | title=International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science | edition=2nd | editor1-last=Feather | editor1-first=John | editor2-last=Sturges | editor2-first=Paul | year=2003 | isbn=0-415-25901-0 | publisher=Routledge | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JD0vL9QQT0sC&pg=596 }} {{cite journal | title=MPhil and PhD library and information science research in Pakistan: an evaluation | first1=Syed Jalaluddin | last1=Haider | first2=Khalid | last2=Mahmood | journal=Library Review | volume=56 | issue=5 | year=2007 | doi=10.1108/00242530710750590 | pages=407–417 | url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/0024-2535.html}} }} == External links == * [http://www.nlp.gov.pk/ National Library of Pakistan - Official site] {{Asia topic|prefix=National Library of | title=[[National library|National libraries]] of Asia}} {{coord|33.726696|N|73.101736|E|source:dewiki_region:PK-IS_type:landmark|format=dms|display=title}} {{Cultural heritage sites in Islamabad Capital Territory |state=expanded}} [[Category:History of Pakistan|N]] [[Category:National libraries|Pakistan]] [[Category:Libraries in Pakistan]] [[Category:ISBN agencies]] [[Category:Islamabad]] [[Category:1951 establishments in Pakistan]] [[Category:Libraries established in 1951]] [[Category:Deposit libraries]] [[Category:Film archives]] [[Category:Photo archives]] [[Category:Research libraries]] [[Category:World Digital Library partners]] [[Category:Legislative libraries|Pakistan]] [[Category:Educational organisations in Pakistan]] [[Category:Pakistan federal departments and agencies]] [[Category:Auditoriums in Pakistan]]

[[File:National Service memorial.jpg|thumb|right|upright|National Service (1939–1960) memorial at the [[National Memorial Arboretum]]]]
The '''National Service Act 1948''' was an [[Act of Parliament]] which extended the [[Conscription in the United Kingdom|British conscription]] of the [[World War II|Second World War]] long after the war-time need for it had expired, in the form of "[[National Service in the United Kingdom#After 1945|National Service]]". After a bill with the same purpose had been approved in 1947, expected to be implemented 1 January 1949, the [[Cold War]] and the [[Malayan Emergency]] caused a revised and extended version of the new legislation to be approved in December 1948, only days before the new arrangements came into force.<ref name=veterans>{{cite web|title=National Service – History|publisher=British Armed Forces and National Service|url=http://www.britisharmedforces.org/ns/nat_history.htm|date=February 14, 2011|access-date=1 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120721065147/http://www.britisharmedforces.org/ns/nat_history.htm|archivedate=21 July 2012|df=}}</ref>
The act had much in common with the [[National Service (Armed Forces) Act 1939|National Service Act]] of September 1939, which it superseded, but its aim was to continue National Service even at times when the country was not at war. The National Service Act of September 1939 had not addressed this issue.
The National Service Act 1948 applied to all healthy young men (women did not have to do National Service) who were not registered as [[conscientious objector]]s. It did not affect the exemption from service of registered conscientious objectors, nor the procedure for registration.
==Background== In 1948, the British post-war government realised the need for an armed forces larger than that which voluntary recruitment could provide. Discussions were soon started in parliament on a new National Service Act with a first such act being approved in July 1947.<ref name=veterans/> This first version was to come into force on 1 January 1949 and established the period of National Service to 12 months. However, financial crises, the advent of the Cold War and the Malayan Emergency caused the act to be amended before coming into force. The amendment was approved in December 1948, with the date in which it would come into force still being 1 January 1949.<ref name=veterans/>
==Differences to the previous act== The act changed the age range from 18–41 to 17–21, and increased the period of service required from 6 to 18 months. As with previous acts, men who completed the service remained on the reserve list for the number of years in the age-range (four years) which started being counted from the moment they finished serving. However, men on the reserve list could only be called for periods of up to 20 days (previous acts allowed the period to be indefinite), and could not be called more than three times.
The act also changed the trades considered [[reserved occupation|essential services]] to the merchant navy, farming and coal mining (previously, essential services were coal mining, shipbuilding, engineering-related trades and—to a limited extent—medicine). Young men working in the essential services were exempted from National Service for a period of eight years. If they stopped working in these industries before this period of eight years ended (that is, before turning 25), they could be called up for National Service.
==Korean War modifications of the act== In October 1950, in response to the British involvement in the [[Korean War]], the service period was extended to two years. To compensate the reserve period was reduced by six months.
==Ending in 1963== National Service ended gradually from 1960. In November 1960 the last men entered service, as call-ups formally ended on 31 December 1960, and the last National Servicemen left the armed forces in May 1963.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.iwm.org.uk/server/show/ConWebDoc.1272 |title=What was National Service? |author=[[Imperial War Museum]] |access-date=4 April 2013 |work=archive.iwm.org.uk}}</ref> ==Support for reintroduction== In 2015 [[Prince Harry]] made a call for bringing back the National Service. <ref>http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3084790/Harry-happy-warrior-Bring-national-service-says-Prince-reveals-encourage-George-Charlotte-join-Armed-Forces.html/</ref><ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/prince-harry/11610690/Prince-Harry-calls-to-bring-back-National-Service.html/</ref><ref>http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/celebrity-life/royals/prince-harry-throws-his-support-behind-national-service-and-reveals-he-is-happy-being-single/news-story/e6bd94dcb07f9f11b528330318802481/</ref> Following the launch of his 2009 film ''[[Harry Brown (film)|Harry Brown]]'', English actor [[Michael Caine]] called for the reintroduction of [[national service]] in the UK to give young people "a sense of belonging rather than a sense of violence".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/story/738277/put-young-people-in-the-army-says-caine|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130929153937/http://news.sky.com/story/738277/put-young-people-in-the-army-says-caine|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-09-29|title=Put Young People In The Army, Says Caine|date=2013-09-29|access-date=2018-02-14}}</ref>
==See also== * [[National Service in the United Kingdom]]

'''NetHui''' is New Zealand's multi-stakeholder [[web conference]] on [[Internet governance]] and policy issues.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.apnic.net/publications/news/2014/discussing-the-next-25-years-of-the-internet-at-nethui-2014 |title=Discussing the next 25 years of the Internet at NetHui 2014 |date=July 8, 2014 |publisher=[[APNIC]] |accessdate=January 2, 2015}}</ref> NetHui 2014's statement of [[wikt:kaupapa|kaupapa]], which also appears on the [[NZNOG]] website, reads:
{{Quote|NetHui is a community event where everyone's opinions and ideas are equally valued. The event is open to all people regardless of age, background, gender or ethnicity... A respectful open attitude towards others is expected from all participants, speakers, exhibitors and volunteers. Harassment of any kind will not be tolerated and may result in your removal from the event.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://2014.nethui.org.nz/2014/07/nethui-kaupapa |title=NetHui Kaupapa |date=July 14, 2014 |authorlink=Jordan Carter |publisher=NetHui |accessdate=January 2, 2015}}</ref>}}
[[InternetNZ]] provides the NetHui platforms and events along with various interested people, organisations and other sponsors. The NetHui brand is recognised as a leading [[Internet Governance Forum]] meeting.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://2014-south.nethui.org.nz/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/NetHui-South-sponsorship-prospectus_2014.pdf |title=NetHui South 2014 – Sponsorship Prospectus |publisher=NetHui |format=PDF |accessdate=January 2, 2015}}</ref>
==Webinars== {{Expand section|date=May 2018}} [[Sean Plunket]] attended NetHui 2011.
NetHui 2012 included a discussion on "Building online [[Te Reo]] and other multilingual content".
[[Amy Adams (politician)|Hon Amy Adams]], Minister for Communications & Information Technology presented a Ministerial address at NetHui 2013. The International Keynote was given by [[Quinn Norton]]. All sessions and presentations were [[live-streamed]] and video recordings made available from the official site, now archived.
[[Deputy Prime Minister of New Zealand]] Bill English opened NetHui 2014. Differing from previous years, speakers and sessions were [only] live-streamed to maximise [synchronous] participation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://2014.nethui.org.nz/videos |title=NetHui on Video |date=2014 |publisher=NetHui |accessdate=January 2, 2015}}</ref> Afterwards more attention could be paid to New Zealand's most inclusive Web conference as it was [[storify|storified]][https://storify.com/ronmader/nethui]. [[Privacy Commissioner (New Zealand)|Privacy Commissioner]] John Edwards' New Zealand Keynote Address was uploaded to YouTube.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YLVsIjHmJLA] A notable exchange occurred in the session on [[Trolling]] in which blogger G Spite responded to [[David Harvey (jurist)|David Harvey]] with "With all due respect I think your opinion is horseshit."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://glitterandspite.blogspot.co.nz/2014/07/nethui-trolls-and-time-i-swore-at-judge.html |title=Nethui, Trolls and the time I swore at a judge. |date=July 11, 2014 |authorlink=G Spite |accessdate=January 2, 2015}}</ref>
NetHui 2015 is being community-led and is organised to be held again in the [[SkyCity Auckland]] Convention Centre in July.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://nz.finance.yahoo.com/news/dates-announced-nethui-2015-041507875.html |title=Dates announced for NetHui 2015 |publisher=Yahoo Finance NZ |authorlink=InternetNZ |date=Dec 19, 2014 |accessdate=January 2, 2015}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Global Multistakeholder Meeting on the Future of Internet Governance]] *[[World Economic Forum]] *[[LeWeb]]
