{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=August 2013}} {{infobox legislation | short_title = Wildlife Act 1953 | legislature = [[New Zealand Parliament]] | image = Coat of arms of New Zealand.svg | imagesize = 180px | long_title = An Act to consolidate and amend the law relating to the protection and control of wild animals and birds, the regulation of game shooting seasons, and the constitution and powers of acclimatisation societies | introduced_by = | administered_by = | datepassed = 1953 | royal_assent = | date_commenced = | amendments = | related = | repeals = | status = Current }} '''Wildlife Act 1953''' is an Act of Parliament in [[New Zealand]].
Under the act, the majority of native New Zealand vertebrate species are protected by law, and may not be hunted, killed, eaten or possessed. Violations may be punished with fines of up to $100,000.
Wildlife are classified under a number of schedules; all vertebrate species not included in these lists are protected by default. The schedules are periodically amended; for example the [[kea]] was granted full protection in 1984, whereas the [[masked lapwing|spur-winged plover]] (masked lapwing), an Australian species which naturally established itself in New Zealand in the 1930s, had its protected status removed in 2012.
The Act also provides for wildlife sanctuaries, refuges and management reserves.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1953/0031/latest/whole.html?search=ts_act@bill@regulation@deemedreg_Wildlife+Act+1953_resel_25_a&p=1#DLM277211|title=Wildlife Act 1953 No 31 (as at 13 March 2017), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation|website=www.legislation.govt.nz|language=en-NZ|access-date=2017-11-02}}</ref>
==Schedules==
===Schedule 1 - Wildlife declared to be game=== This group comprises commonly hunted waterfowl ([[mallard]], [[Pacific black duck|grey duck]], [[Australasian shoveler]], [[paradise shelduck]], [[black swan]] and [[pukeko]]) and introduced game birds, including [[pheasant]], [[quail]], [[Chukar partridge|chukar]] and [[partridge]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1953/0031/latest/DLM278547.html |title=Schedule 1: Wildlife declared to be game |work=New Zealand Legislation |publisher= Parliamentary Counsel Office |accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref> These birds may be hunted during the open season, which begins in early May and lasts approximately four weeks.
===Schedule 2 - Partially protected wildlife=== This group comprises just the [[little owl]], the [[silvereye]] and, on the [[Chatham Islands]] only, the [[brown skua]] (''Catharacta antarctica lonnbergi'').<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1953/0031/latest/DLM278553.html |title=Schedule 2: Partially protected wildlife |work=New Zealand Legislation |publisher= Parliamentary Counsel Office |accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref> These birds may be shot by landowners if they pose a threat to crops or livestock, without any need for a permit from the [[Department of Conservation (New Zealand)|Department of Conversation]]. This group formerly included the [[kea]], which has been blamed for attacking sheep, but is now considered endangered.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kea|author=Colin Miskelly |url=http://nzbirdsonline.org.nz/species/kea|publisher=NZ Birds Online}}</ref>
===Schedule 3 - Wildlife that may be hunted or killed subject to Minister's notification=== These may be culled on application to the Department of Conservation, subject to whatever restrictions are imposed. This group includes the [[swamp harrier|Australasian harrier]], [[grey teal]], [[grey-faced petrel]], [[mute swan]], [[Great cormorant|black shag]], [[Little pied cormorant|little shag]], [[Australian pied cormorant|pied shag]] and [[sooty shearwater]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1953/0031/latest/DLM278564.html |title=Schedule 3: Wildlife that may be hunted or killed subject to Minister's notification |work=New Zealand Legislation |publisher=Parliamentary Counsel Office |accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref>
===Schedule 4 - Wildlife not protected, except in areas and during periods specified in Minister's notification=== This group formerly consisted of wild [[horses]], which had some degree of protection in the [[Kaimanawa horse|Kaimanawa]] range, but is now obsolete.
===Schedule 5 - Wildlife not protected=== This is a large group that includes many common domestic and introduced species, many of which are regarded as pests. It includes numerous land mammals and birds, three species of Australian ''[[Litoria]]'' tree frogs, the Australian rainbow skink (''[[Lampropholis delicata]]'') and the North American [[red-eared slider]] turtle (''Trachemys scripta elegans'').<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1953/0031/latest/DLM278571.html |title=Schedule 5: Wildlife not protected |work=New Zealand Legislation |publisher=Parliamentary Counsel Office |accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref> The only species on this list that occur naturally in New Zealand are the [[southern black-backed gull]] and the [[spur-winged plover]] (masked lapwing), both of which present a significant risk of [[bird strike]].
===Schedule 6 - Animals declared to be noxious animals subject to the Noxious Animals Act 1956=== This group consists of the [[chamois]], the [[Himalayan tahr]], and all species of [[deer]] (the family Cervidae), goats (the genus ''[[Capra (genus)|Capra]]''), and [[pig]]s (the genus ''Sus'').<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1953/0031/latest/DLM278592.html |title=Schedule 6: Animals declared to be noxious animals subject to the Noxious Animals Act 1956 |work=New Zealand Legislation |publisher=Parliamentary Counsel Office |accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref> All are considered harmful to New Zealand's native forests and may be hunted without restriction.
===Schedule 7 - Terrestrial and freshwater invertebrates declared to be animals=== Under the original legislation, the word "animal" referred only to land-based vertebrates. Schedule 7 was added to give protected status to a number of native invertebrates, most of them endangered. The species include two native [[grasshopper]]<nowiki/>s, many species of beetle including the [[Prodontria lewisi|Cromwell chafer]] and the [[Hadramphus spinipennis|coxella weevil]], all [[giant weta]], the [[katipo]] spider, the [[Spelungula|Nelson cave spider]], and several kinds of native snails including all ''[[Powelliphanta]]'' and ''[[Placostylus]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1953/0031/latest/DLM278595.html |title=Schedule 7: Terrestrial and freshwater invertebrates declared to be animals |work=New Zealand Legislation |publisher=Parliamentary Counsel Office |accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref>
===Schedule 7A - Marine species declared to be animals=== Similarly, this list gives protected status to a number of marine species, including some [[coral]]<nowiki/>s (notably [[black coral]]), several [[shark]]s, and two species of [[Epinephelus|grouper]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1953/0031/latest/DLM278598.html |title=Schedule 7A: Marine species declared to be animals |work=New Zealand Legislation |publisher=Parliamentary Counsel Office |accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=April 2017}} '''Yunker''' Kotei Eki, {{nihongo|''Yunkeru Kotei Eki''|ユンケル黄帝液}}, is a [[health tonic]] similar to [[Lipovitan]] and produced by the Sato Pharmaceutical Corporation in [[Japan]]. It was first produced in 1967,<ref name="Yunkerhistory">{{cite web |url=https://www.yunker.jp/history/|title=ユンケルの歴史|accessdate=April 26, 2017|website=Yunker}}</ref> and is widely available at [[drug stores]] throughout Japan. Yunker contains Chinese [[herbal]] ingredients and [[caffeine]] and is marketed to the Japanese workforce to combat [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]].
It is one of 33 tonics manufactured by Sato for a range of ailments related to fatigue. The Yunker line of tonics is also sold in the [[United States|U.S.]], [[Europe]] and Singapore, but the contents of some tonics have been altered to meet domestic regulations.<ref name="Yunkersg">{{cite web|url=http://www.satopharm.com.sg/product/yunker-kotei-solution|title=Yunker Kotei Solution|accessdate=April 26, 2017}}</ref>
A [[USDA]] report from 2002 reported that exports of ''Yunkeru Kotei-eki'' to six countries including the [[United States]], [[Germany]], [[Canada]] and Singapore were continuing to grow, and that Sato planned to start exports to [[Thailand]] later that year.
==Ingredients== Yunker Kotei contains the following ingredients (quantities are quoted per 30ml daily dose): *sugars: 7g *[[vitamin E]]: 10 IU *[[Thiamin]]: 4.2 mg *[[Riboflavin]]: 3.8 mg *[[Vitamin B6|Vitamin B<sub>6</sub>]]: 5.0 mg *[[Vitamin B12|Vitamin B<sub>12</sub>]]: 2.0μg *[[Niacin]]: 10 mg *[[Sodium]]: 30 mg *[[Royal jelly]]: 100 mg *Barrenwort Fluid Extract (Leaf) 100 mg *Cnidium Fluid Extract (Fruit) 100 mg *Asian [[Ginseng]] Extract (Root) 10 mg *[[Crataegus|Hawthorn]] Berry Extract (Fruit) 3 mg *Viper Tincture 100 mg *Civet Tincture 100 mg
